SPOTLIGHT With the launch of ACA (otherwise known as Obamacare), health insurance is the hottest topic in the media. However, self-employed consultants, contractors and freelancers have been largely overlooked. What does the law mean for them? What is the business and personal impact?
Our December 12 webinar brings insights to help you navigate changes and prepare for a healthy start to 2014. Don’t miss it. <http://www.mbopartners.com/webinars/2013/affordable-care-act-what-independent-workers-need-know>

SCOPING OUT THE STATEMENT OF WORK Successful project management is critical for independent consultants. You have to properly set client expectations up front and deftly manage the project to ensure that those expectations are met. However, it is not uncommon for issues to arise after a project starts. Little requests that were not originally discussed over time can add up to the dreaded “scope creep.”
A good statement of work or scope of work document is a channel that opens up communication between you and your client. As you work to create the document, you can and should explore the boundaries of the project, including what will be done and what is outside of the scope of the agreement. A scope of work document is essentially a blueprint for your project, so it should include overall goals of the project, milestones, and even payment terms.

Gene Zaino President and CEO Connect with Gene <http://www.linkedin.com/in/genezaino> As the conversations in your neighborhood turn to turkey, mistletoe and eggnog, you’ll inevitably hear people comparing vacation time. Some companies are generous, and some can be Scrooge-like. However, as an independent, no one tells you when to vacation; you just have to figure it out.
Your clients will be thinking about their own holiday stressors— they all have in-laws coming to town, too. However, they’ll still be expecting their deliverables when they return (contract documents aren’t known to celebrate any major holidays). So how can independent consultants know when to start booking their vacation without losing valuable business?
